statement: This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, b_i = 1 for all i (1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n). You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem. You find yourself with two arrays of positive integers a and b, both of length n. You will perform the following operation any number of times (possibly none): select an integer i (1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n) and increase a_i by 1. This has a cost of b_i. Determine the minimum total cost to make it so that there exists two integers i, j where 1 â‰¤ i < j â‰¤ n and \gcd(a_i, a_j)^{\text{âˆ—}} > 1.^{\text{âˆ—}}\gcd(x, y) denotes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of integers x and y.
input_specification: InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 10^4). The description of the test cases follows. The first line of each test case contains an integer n (2 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 2 Â· 10^5)Â â€” the length of the array a.The second line of each test case contains n integers a_1,a_2,...,a_n (1 â‰¤ a_i â‰¤ 2 Â· 10^5).The third line of each test case contains n integers b_1,b_2,...,b_n (\color{red}{b_i = 1}).The sum of n across all test cases does not exceed 2 Â· 10^5.
output_specification: OutputFor each testcase, output the minimum cost.
note:
